data.name: paragraph
data.body: When you lift a weight against gravity, it gains potential energy because of its position. As it falls, it gains kinetic energy and loses potential energy. The total energy remains constant. Forces like these are called conservative forces, like the spring force and gravity. The Coulomb force between stationary charges is also conservative. This isn't surprising because both forces depend on distance inversely and differ mainly in their constants. Like how a mass gains potential energy in a gravitational field, a charge gains electrostatic potential energy in an electrostatic field.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: We have an electric field (E) due to a charge (Q) placed at the origin. Now, let's bring a test charge (q) from point R to point P against the repulsive force from charge Q. This scenario occurs when both Q and q are positive or negative. For simplicity, let's assume both are positive.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Two points to note: First, we assume q is very small so it doesn't affect the original setup. Second, we apply an external force ($F_ext$) just enough to counter the electric force (F), so there's no net force on q as it moves from R to P.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The work done by the external force equals the negative of the work done by the electric force, storing potential energy in q. Suppose we remove the external force at P. In that case, the electric force will propel q away from Q, using the stored potential energy to give q kinetic energy, keeping the total energy constant.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The work done against the repulsive electrostatic force is stored as potential energy. At each point in the electric field, a particle with charge q gains electrostatic potential energy. The work done increases its potential energy by an amount equal to the potential energy difference between points R and P. So, the potential energy difference (âˆ†U) from point R to point P is equal to the negative of the work done (W).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Note here that this displacement is in the opposite sense to the electric force and hence work done by the electric field is negative, i.e.$ -W_{RP}$.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: So, we define the electric potential energy difference between two points as the work needed by an external force to move (without accelerating) charge q from one point to another in an electric field created by any arbitrary charge configuration.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: 1 )  The work done by an electrostatic field to move a charge from one point to another only depends on the initial and final points and is not affected by the path taken between them. This is a fundamental feature of conservative forces. If the work depended on the path, the concept of potential energy wouldn't make sense. The fact that the work done by an electrostatic field is independent of the path can be demonstrated using Coulomb's law.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: 2 ) Potential energy difference is defined using the physically meaningful quantity of work. This implies that the actual value of potential energy isn't physically significant; only the difference in potential energy matters. Adding an arbitrary constant to potential energy at every point won't change the potential energy difference.In simpler terms, we have the freedom to choose where the potential energy is considered zero. A convenient choice is to set the electrostatic potential energy to zero at infinity.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: If we consider point R to be at infinity the U at R will be 0.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Now, we can define Potential Energy  as :

data.name: bold
data.body: The potential energy of charge q at a point (in the presence of a field due to any charge configuration) is the work done by the external force (equal and opposite to the electric force) in bringing the charge q from infinity to that point.
